info.event: Start by identifying the trigger that brought up difficult emotions or thoughts. A trigger can be anything — from a major event to something very small, or even just a fleeting thought.
info.thought: An automatic thought appears in response to an event and sets off a wave of emotions. These emotions can intensify and generate new negative thoughts, creating a vicious cycle. To keep it from growing, try to notice the automatic thought as early as possible and write it down.
info.body: Recall the moment the trigger appeared and pay attention to your body. What exactly did you feel physically? Which unpleasant sensations did you notice?
info.behavior: How did you behave after these emotions appeared? What did you do — or, on the contrary, what did you avoid doing?
info.response: When you notice an automatic thought, it’s important to look at it carefully. Such thoughts often contain cognitive distortions and logical errors. Your task is to find a rational, more realistic response and turn it into a supportive belief.
info.conclusion: Describe the conclusions you came to: did your emotional state change, how do you now see this situation, and what would you like to try next time in similar circumstances?
info.comparison: Write down the arguments that support the automatic thought and those that contradict it. This will help you evaluate it more objectively and see the situation from a broader perspective.

stepper.event: I made a mistake on a task at work
stepper.thought: I feel like I make mistakes often, and because of that people around me treat me badly
stepper.body: I felt my heart start racing and a heaviness in my chest
stepper.behavior: I abruptly shut the door and walked out
stepper.response: Everyone makes mistakes — they’re a natural part of work and learning. One error doesn’t define me as a professional or as a person. I can’t know for sure what others actually think, and my assumptions about their attitude may be much harsher than reality.
stepper.conclusion: If a similar situation happens again, I’ll try not to jump to conclusions about other people’s reactions. If I’m unsure, I can clarify the situation directly instead of guessing. I’ll also create a short checklist to review tasks before submitting them, so I can feel more confident and reduce the likelihood of similar mistakes.

description: Turn journaling from a routine task into a creative, engaging process. Instead of simply listing events, try telling the story of your day as a short narrative.
AI will support you by analysing your story and suggesting the optimal way to fill in the diary, selecting suitable categories and fields.
You can always edit and add to what AI suggests so that your entry stays as personal and accurate as possible.
Your text will be saved in the diary, so it won’t disappear after the analysis and will always be available to you.
AI makes working with your thoughts not only useful but also inspiring, turning journaling into a space for self-expression and self-care.
hint: Describe the event, your feelings and your thoughts. In your story, try to include:
Which emotions and physical sensations you experienced
Your adaptive response to this automatic thought
What conclusion you drew from this situation

automaticAnalysis.title: Recording emotions instead of thoughts
automaticAnalysis.description: Feelings cannot be refuted in an adaptive response and should be recorded in a separate step.
automaticAnalysis.right: I think I won’t be able to cope

automaticAnalysis.title: Vague formulations
automaticAnalysis.description: An automatic thought may be recorded too generally.
automaticAnalysis.right: I think my colleagues consider me incompetent

automaticAnalysis.title: Recording facts instead of interpretations
automaticAnalysis.description: It is important to note your attitude toward the event. The fact of the event was recorded in the previous step.
automaticAnalysis.right: Now my boss will think I’m irresponsible

automaticAnalysis.title: Too complex and confusing formulation
automaticAnalysis.description: Thoughts should be recorded simply and clearly; otherwise, it will be difficult to provide an adaptive response.
automaticAnalysis.wrong: I tend to believe that my opinion doesn’t matter
automaticAnalysis.right: My opinion doesn’t matter to anyone

automaticAnalysis.title: Skipping the automatic thought
automaticAnalysis.description: Some people immediately record alternative thoughts or responses to automatic thoughts.
automaticAnalysis.right: I’m not sure I can handle it

automaticAnalysis.title: Ignoring key thoughts
automaticAnalysis.description: Sometimes people only record thoughts that seem more acceptable, ignoring key or painful automatic thoughts.
automaticAnalysis.wrong: I’m a bit worried about the future

smer.h2: Establish a Connection with Automatic Thoughts
texts: Intermediate beliefs are rules based on which we perceive reality.
Distorted beliefs lead to destructive thoughts, which we call automatic thoughts.
In this section, you can establish a connection between these concepts for further exploration.
